title: Ticket #2726: condor_q fails with error, "Two clusters with the same ID"
description:
Brian reports the following strange behavior using code from the current trunk: 

$ condor_q -pool red-condor.unl.edu -name red-gw2.unl.edu -format '%s' ResidentSetSize
Error: Two clusters with the same ID.
tempCPS: -1 -1 -1 -1
Comparing against: -1 -1 -1 -1

I reverted 99f1b6974e9d7823b5587ed11860b82fde66c32f (from #1281), recompiled condor_q (not the schedd), and the problem went away.
remarks:
2011-Dec-21 11:07:19 by nwp:
On IRC, Brian reports using the -stream option. But then this code path would have been avoided, by my reading of the code.

2011-Dec-21 11:14:32 by danb:
When using the -stream option, the error does not happen. The error only happens when I do not use the -stream option.

2011-Dec-21 11:17:29 by bbockelm:
Sorry about that - I copy/pasted the working command, not the broken command, on IRC. It does succeed with -stream.

2011-Dec-21 11:39:56 by nwp:
I added code which fixed this specific problem, and tested it successfully by querying UNL. I'll leave the ticket open in case Brian turns up more issues with my fix for #1281. We need a regression test for this; the problem happens with glideins, correct? Is there a way to test glideins?

2011-Dec-21 11:45:40 by danb:
condor_q -analyze has a -jobads option. I wish -jobads worked more generally in condor_q. Then perhaps a regression test for this and other cases would be easier to write.
check_ins: 2011-Dec-21 11:30   Check-in [28889]: Allow condor_q to sort with negative clusterID ===GT=== #2726 Fix the bug below, noticed by Brian Bockelman: [...] (By Nathan W. Panike )
creator: danb
